fields.intro: Have you ever thought of creating your own custom map and displaying it using Google Maps? Well, I did and I want to share the experience. The goal was to be able to use an old map to display a kayak trip I did some time ago..

This post explains how to add your own thumbnails in Google Maps. I did it for one of my websites in a very similar way as Panoramio does it. In fact You could use Panoramio, but if you're not willing to share your pictures then this is a good alternative.

Have you ever tried to include Skype links in a Wordpress menu? If the answer is yes then you know that it's not something that will work by default. Wordpress sanitation function will prevent it from working..
Some of you may be familiar with sweetCaptcha, a fun and simple captcha service. It's one of the captcha services I usually use. I've just released a package to integrate it with Laravel 4..

fields.body:
[{"type": "content", "value": "

Not long ago I discovered Bower, a package manager for web resources such as CSS and JS. I used to copy/paste all the needed resources to each one of my projects. You know what I'm talking about here: downloading jQuery and Twitter Bootstrap all the time, copying them into the project folder, etc.. Enough of that crap. Bower enables you to automatically install those required resources and manage them as you may like in your development process.

"}, {"type": "image", "value": {"attribution": "", "alternative_title": "", "license_name": "", "image": 6, "caption": "", "license_url": ""}}, {"type": "content", "value": "

Bower depends on Node\u00a0and npm, so be sure you have those installed in your system before proceeding.

"}, {"type": "code", "value": {"code": "npm install -g bower", "language": "bash"}}, {"type": "content", "value": "

Now, in your Laravel project folder you should choose a folder where Bower is gonna put all the resources we want to install. I usually like to put it under the public\u00a0folder. Let's create a folder named bower_resources\u00a0under the public\u00a0folder. Using your favorite editor or the command line you should create a file named .bowerrc\u00a0in the root of your Laravel project. In this file you override the default directory where Bower installs all the resources:

"}, {"type": "code", "value": {"code": "{\r\n \"directory\": \"public/bower_resources\"\r\n}", "language": "html"}}, {"type": "content", "value": "

Now Bower is able to save the dependencies whenever we install a resource. Using the bower install\u00a0command and the -S\u00a0flag, install the popular jQuery\u00a0library:

"}, {"type": "code", "value": {"code": "bower install jquery -S", "language": "bash"}}, {"type": "content", "value": "

If you check your public/bower_resources\u00a0you're gonna see a jquery\u00a0folder with the library contents in it. Awesome right? Well there's much more. You can manage your dependencies for development and production environments. Check the Bower\u00a0documentation to know more about all the possibilities Bower offers you.

Another cool thing is that we don't longer have to keep track of our resources in our code repository. We don't need to commit the public/bower_resources, we just need to commit .bowerrc\u00a0and bower.json and when we run Bower the resources folder will be created and filled with all of our resources!

Enjoy!

"}]
fields.intro: Not long ago I discovered Bower, a package manager for web resources such as CSS and JS. I used to copy/paste all the needed resources to each one of my projects. You know what I'm talking about here: downloading jQuery and Twitter Bootstrap all the time, copying them into the project folder, etc.. Enough of that crap. Bower enables you to automatically install those required resources and manage them as you may like in your development process.
Polymorphic relations are one of the many great features Laravel has to offer. Let's illustrate how to effectively use them through a very simple example!

The last few months I've been doing a good amount of work using Wagtail. Wagtail is a pretty cool CMS built on top of the Django framework. It hasn't been around for long but it has a pretty active community and a nice documentation. I've built a couple of relatively large sites with it and been quite happy with the result so far.

fields.body:
[{"type": "content", "value": "

I recently co-wrote an article for my current company, Springload, about the Wagtail CMS. For those of you who do not know, Wagtail is an awesome CMS built on top of Django, a Python-based framework. If you would like to know a bit more about Wagtail you should read the full article. Enjoy!

"}]
fields.intro: I recently co-wrote an article for my current company, Springload, about the Wagtail CMS. For those of you who do not know, Wagtail is an awesome CMS built on top of Django, a Python-based framework. If you would like to know a bit more about Wagtail you should read the full article. Enjoy!

fields.body:
[{"type": "content", "value": "

At Springload, the place I currently work, we've recently released Made with Wagtail, a showcase of websites built with the Wagtail CMS. I recommend you guys to check it out if you're interested in this cool CMS built on top of Django.

One of the many cool features this CMS ships with is the form builder. It allows you to create a form page from the admin backend choosing the number of field you want. It also comes with a default interface where and administrator can see the submissions and their values. Cool stuff!!

Unfortunately, it doesn't give you the option to add a captcha field to the form. That why I thought of somehow, try to integrate SweetCaptcha in the builder. I previously built a plugin to integrate it with Laravel so I knew it wasn't a complicated job.

After looking around for some existing stuff, I found an existing Python package, from where I took the main client class. First I did the Django field, wrapping it in a package, the repo being in https://github.com/jordij/django-sweetcaptcha

Then I did the Wagtail integration, you can access the repo in https://github.com/jordij/wagtailsweetcaptcha

Installation and usage is really easy. Once you've installed and done the settings, you just need to declare you FormPage class inheriting from one the available form classes in the package, depending if you'd like to enable email notification for each form submission or not. As I said it's pretty straightforward, in case of doubts read the docs or send me message.

Enjoy!

"}]
fields.intro: At Springload, the place I currently work, we've recently released Made with Wagtail, a showcase of websites built with the Wagtail CMS. I recommend you guys to check it out if you're interested in this cool CMS built on top of Django.

fields.body:
[{"type": "content", "value": "

Due to all malware issues problems caused by SweetCaptcha I decided to write another captcha package for Wagtail under my current's company repo.

This time I thought that I'd go for a reliable and proven captcha provider such as Google's ReCaptcha. And I didn't even need to write a Django package first because django-recaptcha was already there.

So if you need a reliable captcha field for you Wagtail form pages go to the Github repo or the Python Package Index and take it from there.

Springload's excellent Made with Wagtail listing site is using it in production. See the code in the repo.

"}]
fields.intro: Due to all malware issues problems caused by SweetCaptcha I decided to write another captcha package for Wagtail under my current's company repo.
